Early Access Review

Are you:
A fan of eating?
A fan of flesh?
A fan of flesh eating?
If you're a fan of eating, then you've come to the wrong place. Steam is a game retailer, not your local food court. Similarly, if you're a fan of the latter two, then you're a either a pervert or a cannibal and should seek help. Regardless of your strange fetishes, Flesh Eaters is the game you’ve been looking for. (not really)
Seriously though, seek help.

With that out of the way, I’ll be scrutinizing the game and everything I can fit within the hour. Moving on to the game, every aspect of it, be it gameplay, controls and visuals, are all as you’d expect of an early access game. These range from typical game crashes (a staple of any noteworthy game in beta), clunky and laggy controls, to endearing AI antics where both zombies and humans alike refuse to do anything except molest doors and have intense staring contests with one another. A shame though that the zombies look more like Saibamen with ♥♥♥♥♥♥-like mouth holes, if not I’d have guffawed at the potential romance.

Gameplay wise, Flesh Eaters plays more like a slow-paced strategy game. So if you’re expecting to personally deal deliverance onto grotesque hell-spawn who failed to reach the river Styx, you won’t find it here. You do however, get satisfaction if you manage to plan and coordinate your characters - a squad of four humans, comprised of three potential classes. Though, experiencing the peril of being surrounded by naked abominations as each quarter of your own self dies isn’t bad in itself either.

Supposedly, we’ll be seeing a bunch of updates and promises of a campaign and the like. So, there’s that to look forward to. The game is currently on sale at ¢15, with trading cards on the way, so you’ll likely be able to make your money back there. At 10MB, I’m sure even toasters will be playing this game within the not-so-far future.

Apparently, the game was given away for free (I can't substantiate this, since I can't be bothered to google though). You know what I could’ve gotten for 15 cents? 15 cents worth of games, that’s what.
If nothing else, 15 cents is alot cheaper than a single mp3 you'd find elsewhere.

So with updates on the way, there’s no way the game will get any worse ((see: ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥) (addendum:see sarcasm)) , and at the price the game is currently at, you have nothing to lose save for the 15 cents you spent.

TL;DR - Sandbox is okay for for a little bit, campaign is, simply, not  fun.

When I bought this in early access, it seemed to initially have a great deal of potential. However, the devs have done nothing to improve the overall gameplay experience since it first went EA. The controls are infuriating, as there is no precision when clicking on a target...Click on a zombie to shoot it, and your survivor runs straight into his loving arms to have his face eaten. The sandbox got old rather quickly due to its repetitive nature, but I had hoped the campaign might offer some change of pace.

However, the campaign mode is absurdly frustrating. Basically, an RNG decides what events are available, which determines what resources are available. For example, If you don't have any ammo, then you can't play a level that provides no ammo, or you will be killed immediately. Given that you only have 30 campaign actions (e.g. search something, play a level, save your game) before you die, and way too many objectives to complete, the campaign is ruthlessly difficult. After about 15 attempts, I decided that there really is little point in playing anymore, since it wasn't even fun by that point. I had hoped for more from this game.

Considering the low price point, I want to give the devs the benefit of the doubt, so expectations of graphics, sound, and grammar/sentence structure can be overlooked. Even so, this one is going away to the another dissapointment" section of my library. This is mostly because the game just isn't any fun after a short while due to its RNG-ish nature."

Early Access Review

I don’t usually like writing in my reviews like this, but since I have no idea where to start, I’m going to use a pro and con format while expanding on each one.

You can take this with a grain of salt, since I’m not used to critiquing games.
Also, I haven’t experience everything in the game, and might have missed key factors.

I will probably play more in the future, and update this review/log or whatever.

These are honestly mostly suggestions on how to make the game better, more then a review, and I’m not sure if this place is appropriate or not, but oh well.

Pros
+easy and simple layout
I would appreciate if they added a bit more context for test lab, perhaps a brief explanatory for each mode. While the rest of the maps are self explanatory, the name should be changed for test lab because it isn’t self explanatory. You have no idea what’s going to happen when playing test lab. Also, a undo or back button would be nice when choosing the difficulty over constantly resetting the game.

Cons
-No time for strategy
Holy ♥♥♥♥, this is a huge issue I had with the game. Controlling multiple characters at the same time in such a confined area is a nightmare. It isn’t fun or engaging, it’s unfair hard.
You’re going to constantly misclick since everything is so packed tight together, and the the hotkey for choosing each character is even worse. You have no sense in which number selects one character, and constantly going through all the numbers before getting the right one within the few seconds the game demands you to execute.

It’s especially hard for new players who have no idea what’s going on. You don’t teach the player that you need wood and metal to create barricades within 50 seconds, give time for each player to examine the area and get used to it.
Don’t add a time limit, but at the beginning of the game, let the zombies come once you reached a certain point when the player is ready for zombies.

There are plenty of ways to fix this, add a pause button. No, not the one you currently have. let the player be able to pause the game and examine what to do, give them a little space to breathe. Let them be able to control where the character role fits while still in the pause menu, before the plan is taking to action after you unpause the game. It’s better than constantly managing multiple characters while having zombies after you in real time.
If you don’t understand what I’m explaining (which I understand, I explained it pretty badly), I recommended you a game called, “FTL: Faster Than Light”, it allows the player to strategize before making their actions. And no, it wouldn’t make the game easier. FTL is hard as balls, yet it’s mechanics are extremely easy to master. Create a proper learning curve and give the player a chance to get used to it’s surrounding within the first playthrough. This doesn’t mean the game has to be easy, just make it harder as the player progress.

If you don’t like that idea, how about the medic is able to slow down the game so the player can examine the area and strategize while playing? So, you can organize all of the characters properly while simultaneously fending off.


-Graphics
This is honestly just kind of a nitpick of mine, but the arms look ♥♥♥♥ing hideous.
Funny at first, but it gets distracting real fast.

-no explanation or hotkey
The game just drops you and tell you what role this character is, and put it in this certain room to gather material.
It doesn’t explain that you need wood to barricaded windows, or that you need this for that.
Neither does it explain which hotkey does what. What’s the key for healing your teammates with the medic? Do you left click him? do you right click him? Nope! I still don’t know how to ♥♥♥♥ing heal my teammates.
A little guidance would help, but don’t constantly hold my hand during the entire playthrough.
Or just let the player decided the pacing of the game in the beginning, just like how I mentioned earlier.

The only way you learn how the game works, is constantly dying and learning new mechanics. Which is fine, I love dark souls, and the foundation of the game revolves around that. But the key difference between the two is that, one is fair, and the other is not. I already explained earlier how it’s unfair. But even then, dark souls still did a good job explaining how the game works right from it’s tutorial and it felt fair when you died. Majority of the time I died in this game simply from unorganized character clustering around in one area not doing what I planned them to do because it never explained how to do this stuff or which buttons to press.

Other stuff that was on my mind when I was playing:

A multiplayer would be nice. Maybe a vs mode when one player is controlling the zombies, while the other player is defending the place.

Cheap game. Didn’t really include this in the positive because the price of the game doesn’t have any effect on the gameplay itself. Unless we're talking about DLCs or add ons

What’s the point of a story mode? It seems kind of off when you consider how the game works, and how will it function?
Will it just be a exactly the same ♥♥♥♥ing thing as the survival? I really hope not, just please add more depth to the story mode then just adding a new layout of the game. That’s just lazy.

it has a lot of potential and could be a more action based game then FTL. It just needs to get over the cloggy controls and unreasonable fast pace.

Introduction
You take control of a group of survivors and use their skills to barricade windows and doorways, build turrets, and take down the undead while working on your escape vehicle.
The game provides features such as: Equipping and upgrading different weapons and armour
Leveling up to upgrade your survivor stats
Gathering resources to build barricades and defend against the horde.
Fighting against various types of zombies
Offers 3 different survivor classes to choose from: soldier, medic and engineer which has 3 unique skills each.Several game modes are fully functional with 3 difficulty levels. Due to the fact that this game is still in Early Access, the story mode with an expanded map outside is still in development.

Pros:
+ Trading cards
+ Achievements (planned)
+ Excellent team of developers who constantly update the game

Cons:
-  Only playable in single player
- Instruction guide which pops up are annoying (might be because of my limited ability)
- Early in access still, not fully complete

Conclusion:
Promising elements of a very good Real Time Strategy and Role Playing Game. I definitely recommend this game to anyone that is, a fan of zombie survival games or zombies in general and looking for a game they can enjoy for a long time.

The game is okay, but I have my reasons for that. I adore games like these, with survival being the main point of the game, and this game has some good points but every good point is shot down by bad points. Let me start off with some of the pros.

-Multiple characters that you can choose to fit your play style: Feel like being a badass who doesn't need any healing? Go ahead and have only soldiers on your side. Feel like planning a bit and staying in a hole of protection? Go with a mixture of soldiers, mechanics, and healers like I do, or even if you feel like challenging yourself you can do so by getting only one soldier and the rest are medics. This is fun and varies the gameplay a bit.

-Waves give you time to do things inbetween them: You have no clue how many games I've played where the waves go by so fast that you have no time to upgrade your weapons or anything. It sucks when that happens and adds a difficulty that I don't exactly enjoy, especially when the upgrade station is so far away from where the main objective is.

-Fairly good graphics: This one seems a bit of a stretch in reaching for good things, but hear me out. So the top down perspective is hard to work with, but that's not all the graphics have to offer. There's small details in the menues that made me chuckle a bit because it's lighthearted and rather nice to see in a zombie game, and the upgrade menu has a nice feel to it too.

-The upgrade system: Now, this one is kinda nice. You can upgrade anyone at any time, if you have the materials. Even the armor can get upgrades! Your armor can break though so beware of that. The mechanics get some turrets and such, the medics I haven't touched because of reasons I'll get into later, and the soldiers get gun and armor upgrades. It's nice to see the visual change of your character too when you upgrade.

Now for the cons...

-Terrible character movement: When you click on an area for your character to go they can often flip out. You have to click on an area for the character to go there, which is normally not a bad thing, but whenever you click the character can often get stuck on something, or even slip around while trying to move, which segues into my next point.

-Glitchy movement: Your character, if you click multiple times, can spaz out. The first time I clicked three times the character slipped through the wall and out of the main map. This part sucks and I had trouble dealing with it. It happens multiple times and I feel like it's due to poor programing on the character part.

-Overpowered zombies: So this was kind of a huge issue for me. Your first wave starts out easy (Mind you that I'm playing on easy because I'm learning things) but as soon as that second wave comes around you're screwed. The zombie killed my soldier in two hits, or some really fast hits that seemed to do a lot of damage. I couldn't escape because of two issues, one is the terrible movement with the glitchy spazment, and the other is my next gripe.

-The slow character movement: Your characters are barely faster than the zombies! The rooms are about as big as a normal house, right? Then why is it that the characters walk like they took too many drinks and are hobbling slowly because they'll fall otherwise? I don't like that. I'll move on to my next issue

-The door mechanics: So this should be simple, yes? Well, it's not. Since story mode isn't available yet we have to go with sandbox, which isn't too big of an issue. reviewText:
Flesh Eaters is an excellent zombie survival indie game that combines tower defense like mechanism with team building where you spend experience on making your team members improve in the areas of your choice. You can also craft new equipment  (weapons, for example). This requires crafting materials you can collect in different ways. After the tutorial you have 30 days in story mode to complete it. Each day is one action you decide from three available options randomly generated for that day. This means you can pretty much lose the game in 5 minutes by choosing the wrong options or you can win it in an hour or two, by extending the time you have to finish (visiting the shelter gives you 3 extra days).

The gameplay for the story mode is very demanding and requires throughout planning. That is why so many reviewers gave this game a negative review, which pretty much baffles me. Getting to a point where you can extend the time you need to level up and prepare for getting 100% in the game's tasks is relatively easy, and from there you can restock ammo, from the Save us! event, for example.

There's many different approaches, depending on the way you want to play. I chose the glass cannon approach and invested heavily into ranged weapons, totally neglecting any kind of protective gear. It's possible to craft protective vests and approach the zombies directly, though, so if you're keen on saving up ammo you can follow different ways of obtaining resources.

As I mentioned before, you get to pick from 3 randomly generated actions, and they could either give you a roullette kind  of outcome - lose hp or get a fair amount of certain resources - or let you save the game at this point, or allow you to attempt one of the tower defense kind of maps, where you can assign your team to do certain tasks.

Whether you level them up to be faster and more efficient in gathering materials up, or more effective in combat is up to you.

I highly recommend Flesh Eaters, as it's a great game for that price and very fun to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Flesh Eaters is a small indie zombie survival RTS. It features barricading mechanics, crafting, and zombies. Lotsa zombies. The game's story mode is not yet out. The game is fairly basic for an RTS squad based game, theres 3 classes that you can utilize, engineer(Who can make turrets and mines), medic(Who has a healing aura), and soldier(Who shoots stuff). The engineer can give himself melee weapons, but thats pointless as zombies can inflict countless debuffs on you, usually killing the inflicted within 15 seconds. The medic can't fight(I believe), making the soldier class the best offensive class. Sort of. The engineer can still make turrets, which can't be attacked and can still wipe out plenty of zombies. (I usually roll with 4 soldiers, 1 medic, and 1 engineer.)
So, in terms of gameplay, you start off in small map that may evoke wonderful memories of the original SAS: Zombie Assault flash games. Theres barricades, you fix them by using wood, which theres a box of, you use metal and wood together to craft your soldier some better armor, and eventually, some power armor. Each unit can also reecive level ups, for 5 traits(Health, speed, looting, barricading, hand combat). In early game, you should level up really quickly, and maybe even end up max rank before the special infected show up. More on that later, but there are some problems I should point out, firstly pathfinding can occansionally screw up, and when you try to correct that by pressing somewhere else, your unit continues walking on, blissfully unaware of the zombie horde about to close in on him.
Like many a zombie game, each wave progressively gets more difficult, in terms of zombie numbers and special infected popping up. Theres your regular zombie, fast zombie, fat zombie, and armored zombie. There may be more, but i've either beaten the objective mode too quickly, or died too early.
So, all together, I enjoyed this game. Its simplier than other RTS games, but thats not a problem. For a cheap price of under a dollar, i'd say you should pick it up.

This is a great game so far. The elements of a good rts/rpg are there I love it how random events occur throughout the levels and how each class has various items unique to them. I can't wait to see what this game will look like in the future. I definatly felt the stress every time a new wave hit and where to position my survivors to keep them all out of harms way.

That being said I know this is in Alpha and it is great but there are a few things I noticed. The engineer and medic classes felt a little bit like a waste of space since it costs so much at the work bench to upgrade them. Now since this is a survival game resource managemnet and strategy as which items to buy I defiantly felt the preassure to choose. Do I buy my soldier that new gun or get hazmat gear for the engi or get that new medkit for the medic. I absolutely loved that, but the fact that the medic and engi aren't really useful until you get those items then just felt like mindless mining drones. I also felt a bit lost when learning how to play even with the explanations placed I didn't see much of it in action and as a player I had to resort to a lot of trial and error.

The survirors themselves also had some issues pathing even when it was clear of closed doors and other characters when I gave them a command to move I often found them spinning in circles and dying as a result.

Again I know this is an Alpha and things are going to change but after playing it these are just a few things i noticed. The devs are really doing a great job so far I feel like this game has a bright future :) keep it up guys

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In theory a good idea for a game, Flesh Eaters' execution is shallow and it's full of bugs. When a large horde of zombies is attacking, I find that it's safest to pack your people together in one room. If you do this though, they'll all get stuck on the door, so you'll need to back them up and slowly move them in one-by-one. That's not good when the horde is rapidly closing on you.

When you're in the room, if that room is a small room (there's a small room with no windows or doors to the outside, for example, creating an essential chokepoint for zombies at the one entrance) then your dudes will bump against each other and push each other THROUGH the walls, leaving them outside the building entirely and easy prey for the zombies. If you manage to keep all your people inside then your chokepoint will affect the zombies the same way it affected your dudes when they tried to enter - they'll get stuck on the door, sometimes making it easier to shoot them or (more often) snagging them in a way that leaves them unable to attack you and you unable to attack them, so you'll have to leave your room to finish them off.

On top of that, there is no campaign mode, no multiplayer and there are no achievements. The characters have problems using much of what they've crafted and the engineer class seems underpowered compared to the other two. The developers say they'll be releasing the full version in three months. Judging by the slow progress of the game so far, it's going to be released in an unfinished state. It needs more than tweaks and fixes to be brought up to an acceptable standard, it needs a complete overhaul.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI want story mode so bad! The leveling and customization is great but you really don't feel the impact in a single mission. Once your guys transfer between levels I'll be so happy! I love to build teams that cover each other's weaknesses effectively while still staying within the limitations of my resources and can't wait to tackle mission after mission with them. I will admit that since the engineer and medic don't start with items they feel really lack luster early on and you end up just maxing there looting so you can actually make some use of them and there kits. But once you get there stuff there awesome, however the medic needs to be kept close to your work bench so you can swap between the cure for bleeding and infection at a moment's notice. Melee is a very bad idea even with a maxed out medic as you need to max two stats in order to make it work and even then the medic must stay safe yet close. Prioritizing the types of loot as well as the locations is also fun. Some cashes are easy to get to and defend but run out quickly. Others leave you in places where you can get swarmed but you can get insane amounts of supplies from them over a long time. Over all this is looking to be an amazing little game that is fantastically fun for a very low price.

Early Access Review

Yes this game is still in Alpha, however I must say this game is already quite entertaining and such a good time waster, with only more updates to come ;).  This game you should know that it is purposefully difficult (Like any zombie apocolypse game should be), unlike darksouls with all the difficult bosses (There are no bosses in this game as far as I believe).  Just know once your main form of defence is down, there is no going back, with this game not being ashamed to kill off your entire team in a matter of 30 seconds.  This game is frustrating at times, but once you get the hang of it, while upgrading your men, and figuring out a sence of strategy, this game gets easier but does not stay easy.
This game might not be that revolutionary compaired to big companies like Bethesda or Ubisoft with hundreds if not thousands of workers, but that does not make a small indie game like this bad, this is a fun little game.  All in all, I would recemmend this game to those who are interesting in a fun, stand alone, survival indie game.
